info.game_comments: (Sarah: Clues from the Wild West next on Jeopardy!--so kick back... and enjoy the show.)

double_jeopardy_round: ON THE INDEX OF FORBIDDEN BOOKS

(1, 1).clue: These 2 explorers who eventually teamed up were both born in Virginia in the 1770s

(2, 1).clue: (Sarah rounds up the clue.) A "honda" is a loop used by cowboys to make this tool of their trade

(3, 1).clue: The forbidden love of Lun Tha & Tuptim inspires Anna to sing"Hello, Young Lovers" in this musical

(4, 1).clue: The standard form of this language is based on the Central dialect, the speech in & around Moscow

(5, 1).clue: He's one of the Pep Boys

(6, 1).clue: This rock star was married to Courtney Cobain

(1, 2).clue: WHile visiting Europe, this markswoman once shot a cigarette from the mouth of future Kaiser Wilhelm II

(2, 2).clue: (Sarah fires off the clue.) It's the numerical term for this self-defense necessity

(3, 2).clue: Hodel leaves the village of Anatevka to join her husband in Siberia in this classic musical

(4, 2).clue: In the early 1500s Martin Luther translated the Bible into this language using a dialect of Saxony

(5, 2).clue: In "City Slickers II" Jack Palance played Duke, the twin brother of this character

(6, 2).clue: Now Mrs. Steven Spielberg, she was born in Fort Worth, Texas

(1, 3).clue: Just months before his death in 1844, this Mormon founder declared his candidacy for president

(2, 3).clue: (Sarah shows off the clue.) From a Hindi word for a method of tie-dyeing, it's the colorful cowboy accessory I'm wearing

(3, 3).clue: Appassionata von Climax vies with Daisy Mae for the affections of this title yokel

(4, 3).clue: English began to absorb French words after this 1066 event
(4, 3).correct response: the Battle of Hastings (the Norman Conquest)

(5, 3).clue: Need some lignite? Head to this mining town in Gippsland, Australia

(6, 3).clue: With brother Richard, she won the Best New Artist Grammy for 1970

(1, 4).clue: This organizer of the Air National Guard was first elected to the Senate in 1952

(2, 4).clue: (Sarah strolls in with the clue.) These leggings I'm wearing are used to protect a cowboy's legs from branches and underbrush

(3, 4).clue: Traditionally a dancer takes over the role of Laury in the dream-ballet part of this Rodgers & Hammerstein show

(4, 4).clue: The poet Sappho wrote in the Aeolic dialect of this language

(5, 4).clue: Leisure-suited lounge lizard who's starred in a series of video games

(6, 4).clue: The capital of Nevada was named for this frontiersman

(1, 5).clue: This Naval hero in the Spanish-American War served in the Civil War under David Farragut

(2, 5).clue: (Sarah (and friend) heat up the clue.)  A rawhide artist is a ranch hand who's good with this identifying implement

(3, 5).clue: Cotton Blossom performer Ellie May Shipley sings "Life Upon The Wicked Stage" in this Mississippi River musical

(4, 5).clue: This Scandinavian language has many dialects, especially in North Jutland & the island of Bornholm

(5, 5).clue: This Missoula, Montana-born skier's career went downhill at Lillehammer & he won the gold

(6, 5).clue: On '80s TV he had "Growing Pains" as Mike Seaver

(1, 1).clue: In 1609 English astronomer Thomas Harriot used the new telescope to draw maps of this body before Galileo did

(3, 1).clue: Entering the list in the 20th century were all the works by this Existentialist, including "No Exit"

(4, 1).clue: The American Anti-Vivisection Society is against experimentation on these

(5, 1).clue: The Amalienborg Palace & the Thorvaldsen museum are landmarks of this city

(6, 1).clue: Kansas City is known as "The City of" these, like the Trevi in Rome

(1, 2).clue: Johann Magnenus believed there were 3 elements, fire, earth & water, each made up of these, which we can't see

(3, 2).clue: The Bill Watterson comic strip wasn't on the list but these namesakes of the title characters were

(4, 2).clue: The people who were against the decisions made at the second Diet of Speyer & sided with Martin Luther were called these

(5, 2).clue: According to Mr. Manilow, it's "the hottest spot north of Havana"

(6, 2).clue: Lester Young, Count Basie & Charlie Parker played the Kansas City style of this genre of music

(1, 3).clue: In 1656 Christiaan Huygens found time to invent a clock with this new regulator

(3, 3).clue: This 18th century Italian lover's "Memoirs", written in French, probably debuted at No. 1 on the list

(4, 3).clue: It was the "Revolution" that the followers of Ned Lud were against

(6, 3).clue: Opened in 1869, the Hannibal Bridge spanning this river helped make Kansas CIty a railroading center

(1, 4).clue: The machine Denis Papin built in 1690 was the first to use steam to move one of these in a cylinder

(3, 4).clue: His "Salammbo" was shortlisted, as well as his "Madame Bovary"

(4, 4).clue: All this Chinese philosopher born in 551 B.C. wanted was to bring back a golden age & for people to be respectful

(5, 4).clue: In 1491 he entered the University of Krakow, where he became interested in the study of astronomy

(6, 4).clue: After high school Harry Truman worked briefly in the mail room of this newspaper

(1, 5).clue: John Napier's 1614 table of these took the blues out of calculating

(2, 5).correct response: The Attack of the 50 Ft. Woman

(3, 5).clue: If you wanted to drool over his "Pantagruel", you couldn't; it was on the list

(4, 5).clue: The Greeks didn't believe in free will; there was this group weaving a web of destiny

(5, 5).clue: He won the 1945 Pulitzer Prize for Music for the ballet "Appalachian Spring"

(6, 5).clue: (Take a look.) You can visit the Kansas City home and studio of this artist whose work is seen here

(0, 0).clue: In 1993 this country of over 35 million people had 2 official languages; now it has 11
